channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Why certain medications can increase your risk in the heat
item.description: Some medicines affect your ability to sweat, stay hydrated, or even to notice if you're overheating. Doctors say keep taking them, but make sure to keep yourself cool.

item.title: Researchers find that songbirds sometimes get 'divorced'
item.description: A new study from Oxford University finds that a common European songbird sometimes divorces its partner between breeding seasons.

item.title: Global pressure builds on Israel to let more aid into Gaza
item.description: The U.K. says it plans to recognize a Palestinian state, as global pressure builds on Israel to let more aid into Gaza, where a UN-backed panel warns famine is already unfolding.

item.title: U.N. conference to discuss two-state solution for Israel and Palestinians
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep talks with Middle East expert Jon Alterman about a United Nations conference to advance a two-state solution as a way toward peace between Israel and Palestinians.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Global pressure builds on Israel to let more aid into Gaza, the EPA proposes gutting its greenhouse gas rules, an Epstein's longtime confidant says she'll speak with House lawmakers in exchange for immunity.

item.title: Two pairs of sisters compete to be the best 'skippers' in the world
item.description: Team USA's entry in the International Jump Rope Union World Championships, held in Japan this week, includes two pairs of sisters.

item.title: New federal data show a decline in teen suicide
item.description: A new report of an annual federal survey shows that depression episodes and suicidality among teens went down between 2021 and 2024. But one in ten teens still thought seriously about suicide in the past year.

item.title: Cellist Maya Beiser explores women's narratives across history
item.description: Cellist Maya Beiser explores women's resilience through the centuries in her new album, "Salt," starting with the unnamed biblical figure of Lot's wife.

item.title: The man accused of killing four people in a Manhattan skyscraper believed he had CTE
item.description: The gunman accused of walking into a Park Avenue skyscraper in Manhattan and killing four people suspected he had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or CTE — a degenerative brain disease often associated with football players.

item.title: How CTE affects the brain
item.description: NPR's A Martinez speaks with Chris Nowinski, co-founder and CEO of the Concussion Legacy Foundation, about the brain disease chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or CTE.
